unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Two-Proportion Test: Power
question_text:
Which of the statements is/are NOT true about power in the context of a two-proportion test?

I. Large sample sizes will often allow the statistician to find a significant difference between the two proportions if one really exists. II. Low alpha levels will allow the statistician to find a significant difference between the two proportions if one really exists. III. Power will be $1$, the probability of a Type I error.
solution:
Statement I is true; large samples, as long as no additional bias is present, reduce variability, give a better snapshot of the population and reduce both Type I and II errors.

Statement II is false; lower alpha levels require stronger evidence, which increases the chance of missing the change and committing a type II error. Higher alpha levels reduce a Type II error.

Statement III is false; power is $1-p$ and power is the probability of not making a Type II error. A Type II error involves failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is in fact false. A Type I error involves rejecting the null hypothesis when it is in fact true.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'.
